children.text: The speakers frame the week of performances as a lens to examine audience engagement and scripted social media interactions. They emphasize how performances blur the line between authentic labor and performative labor, positioning bodies and digital presence as sites of both artistic and social experimentation.

Discussion centers on Ulman’s use of social media to explore the visibility of unpaid digital labor. By curating content and controlling temporal release, Ulman highlights the labor inherent in maintaining an online persona, linking it to broader conversations about gendered expectations in digital spaces.

Examines the aesthetic strategies of Excellences & Perfections, where careful staging and performative gestures create a sense of perfection and polish. These strategies interrogate the notion of legitimacy in art, exploring how audiences attribute value to visible labor and curated appearances.

Considers audience manipulation through narrative pacing and digital interaction design. By structuring content in serialized formats, Ulman engages audiences’ expectations and emotional investment, revealing the mechanics of attention economies in online culture.

The conversation turns to gendered perceptions of labor and creativity. Ulman’s project foregrounds the gendered scripts that shape reception of performance work, demonstrating how digital platforms can both reinforce and challenge art-world biases.

Explores how social media constraints shape creative practices. Limitations like image quotas and timed releases create aesthetic frameworks that both restrict and inspire users, similar to European working-class aesthetics in their emphasis on discipline and ingenuity under constraint.

Discusses the intersection of neurodivergence and scripted performance. By highlighting rigid structures in content production, Ulman’s work surfaces how audiences perceive controlled versus spontaneous labor, revealing assumptions about cognitive ability and artistic authenticity.

Examines commodification of suffering in social media documentation. Ulman’s strategic visibility of struggle and exhaustion in labor frames emotional labor as both performative and consumable, prompting reflection on the ethics of audience engagement.

Analyzes how subcultural identity and online community norms inform digital aesthetics. Photolog and similar platforms provided spaces for collective recognition, establishing a logic of taste, distinction, and belonging that persists in contemporary digital subcultures.

Explores visual strategies of legitimacy through careful composition, lighting, and repetition. These methods demonstrate the labor of self-presentation and the creation of perceived expertise, linking back to the larger theme of Excellences & Perfections.

Discussion of how digital labor remains largely uncompensated, especially when embedded in creative platforms. Ulman’s approach demonstrates the tension between visibility, recognition, and economic reward in online artistic labor.

Explores audience expectation and emotional engagement, highlighting how serialized content encourages active participation and sustained attention. This analysis foregrounds the mechanics of manipulation inherent in digital storytelling.

Reflects on gendered interpretation of labor and skill in online performance. The work challenges assumptions about who produces labor that is culturally valued versus dismissed, interrogating art-world hierarchies.
Discusses aesthetics of control and refinement in staged social media posts, connecting visual perfection to perceptions of authenticity, authority, and artistic expertise.
Examines the intersection of subcultural practices with platform limitations, demonstrating how constraints like post frequency shape creative expression and community participation.
Addresses broader ethical implications of digital labor visibility, emphasizing audience complicity and the tension between voyeurism and appreciation in online performance.
Reflections on how performance, labor, and social media interaction intersect to create temporally framed, highly curated experiences that redefine notions of artistic and digital legitimacy.
Examines the body as historically constructed and commodified through labor, capitalism, and patriarchal structures, emphasizing mutability and performative possibilities.
Discusses social signaling in digital spaces, including selfies and image backgrounds, and explores how audience attention mediates gendered and eroticized performance.
Analyzes femininity as a socially constructed and performative set of symbols, linking body representation to aesthetics, social fiction, and identity manipulation.
Explores the labor of digital performance, including separation of personal life and content production, highlighting strategies to manage emotional and physical effort.
Reflects on embodiment, vulnerability, and social constraints, critiquing simplistic empowerment narratives and examining permeability, presence, and structural oppression.
Connects personal experience and subcultural knowledge to online performance, including networked subcultures (e.g., Black Tumblr), demonstrating circulation and critical engagement.
Considers recombinant digital image circulation, the shifting social value of bodies online, and structural inequalities in digital representation, with some optimism for diversification.

The pair introduce Photolog, a significant social media platform for Ulman. Both have written extensively about subcultures that developed on Photolog in Argentina and Chile. For more, read Thelot's "Fotolog, Floggers and the aesthetics of platforms" and Ulman's "F/F".

Ulman is formally identified as an Argentine/Spanish artist whose extensive work spans performance, installation, video, and net artworks. She is currently active as a film director, having transitioned to this medium as a way to gain narrative control over the complex elements of her art.

Fotolog was an influential image-sharing platform particularly popular in South America, noted for its design constraint that limited users to sharing only one image daily. This technical limitation was seen as a way to make the free version more enjoyable and fun due to the creativity required within its rigid structure.

The platform served as a crucial meeting point for people with shared interests, fostering the development of various subcultures, including the Cumbieros and Pokemones. These groups utilized the digital space to commemorate their distinct styles and fashion, ultimately facilitating organized real-world social interaction and community formation.

Although Ulman initially felt deep shame regarding her time on Photolog, she now sees this early digital engagement with aesthetics and audience perception as a foundational element of her artistic methodology. Her history with online identity management and the desire to be taken seriously as an artist informed her later, highly conceptualized performances.

Ulman's early aesthetic skills included making and selling clothes, a pursuit which provided the necessary funds to travel and network in bigger cities. This deep engagement with visual culture taught her how to meticulously stage photographs to manage the audience's perception of her social and class markers, concealing her limited resources.

In London, Ulman was surprised by the non-digital focus of the art school environment, where her net art (developed through early knowledge of coding on platforms like Live Journal) was often undervalued or literally disqualified. This resistance validated her perspective that pervasive internet access had become the inescapable norm, a core concept of Postinternet Art.

Ulman recognized that the emerging digital art scene and her academic setting were characterized by a strongly masculine and exclusive culture that dismissed ideas related to performance or conventional femininity. She consciously decided to challenge this ingrained bias by maintaining a feminine appearance while being a respected, serious director.

The three-part, scripted Excellences & Perfections (E&P) performance was a structural critique of idealized "female perfect Behavior" found on social media, intentionally adopting cliché archetypes. Ulman aimed to satirize the narrative of breakdown, apology, and rescue that fuels the online consumption and commodification of suffering.

Ulman explicitly denied the widely circulated rumor that she was illegally accessing locations for E&P, confirming that she "paid for the hotels" used in the performance. She focused immense effort on meticulously staging the affluent interiors to convincingly replicate the consumerist fantasy promoted by privileged social media feeds. This directly contradicts
Dean Kissick's 2014 article published in iD magazine, which descibes Amalia Ulman "sneaking into luxury hotels to take selfies."

The project’s central premise was to manipulate the audience's perception, demonstrating that a visual lie can gain more credibility than actual verbalized truth because people are conditioned to rely on visual narratives. By adopting familiar archetypes, she enabled the audience to easily generate the scripted narrative and draw predictable conclusions.

Ulman identifies the compulsion to constantly update and provide content as a form of "anxious ambition" driven by the fierce competition for popularity and "cultural capital" in virtual environments. This demand transforms self-presentation into a continuous, uncompensated labor that feels like an "endless interview with no interviewers"

E&P was divided into three distinct, scripted phases, each embodying a recognized female stereotype: the cute ingénue, the hyper-sexualized sugar baby, and the cleansed life goddess. This structural use of archetypes, which included staged elements like plastic surgery and drug use, made the narrative instantly comprehensible to the online audience.

This segment focuses on the emotional exploitation inherent in network economies, creating an environment where "the sadder the girl, the happier the troll". Ulman intended to make the audience feel profound discomfort for consuming a narrative of self-destruction and desiring another human's sorrow.  (https://deborahschamoni.com/media/pages/artists/amalia-ulman/bbaac4392f-1696952923/amalia-ulman-e-p-press-s.pdf)

Ulman utilizes the concept of "middlebrow" to characterize the aesthetics and protagonists in her art, reflecting an interest in common, non-elite cultural signifiers. This focus is part of her larger project analyzing the aesthetics of legitimacy and the visual standards imposed by institutions and places of power.

Her aesthetic choices, spanning video essays and installations, are rooted in "European working-class aesthetics," a preference directly linked to her upbringing in a factory-driven region of Spain. She uses this style to move away from the pressure to exoticize her Argentine background for international audiences.

Ulman critically links physical appearance to professional success, pointing out that an artwork's value can escalate based on the artist's perceived beauty or social media followers. This observation underscores the pervasive "electronic economy of looking good," where commercial and cultural values are inextricably tied to curated self-presentation.

El Paneta is Ulman's first feature film, identified as a "dark comedy about eviction" that features her mother. The film signifies a deliberate thematic return to the context of Spain and the "European working-class aesthetics" that fuel much of her critical inquiry.

Ulman revealed that her early reliance on meticulously scripted formats, such as PowerPoint presentations for artist talks, stemmed from her autism and was a strategy to maintain composure and control during public appearances. These initial scripts evolved into video essays that allowed her to be in charge of her narrative and became recognized artworks in themselves.

To ensure separation between her performance and her real life, Ulman condensed a month's worth of content production for E&P into a single week. During the period when her online persona was supposedly self-destructing, Ulman was actually working at a remote meditation retreat "cleaning cabins and cooking vegan meals," reinforcing the fictional nature of her online life.

Ulman has frequently drawn inspiration from cinema, particularly directors like David Lynch, and elements of her second performance, Privilege, reflected this influence. The immersive installation for Privilege included deep red curtains and checkered floors that critics noted created a specific atmospheric quality reminiscent of Lynch's work

61aa3a1d-9fd0-4f53-a90b-aa65e70dcb90.label: ICA Off-Site: Do You Follow? Art in Circulation #3

children.text: What is Postinernt Art?

Postinternet art refers to a “splintered and loosely defined” tendency that entered mainstream art-world discourse in the early 2010s. Often cited as the “last major ‘movement’ in contemporary art” before the field became increasingly atomized, it remains an “odd, elusive, and perhaps ‘embarrassing’ neologism.” As Brian Droitcour noted, “[m]ost people I know think ‘Post-Internet’ is embarrassing to say out loud.” Crucially, the term does not describe art on the internet but art made after the internet—art that assumes an environment in which the web has become an “inescapable, essential” and effectively “disappeared” condition of life. Postinternet work is therefore seen as reflecting the “cultural logic of the internet-enabled stage of late capitalism in the 2010s.”

Departing from the earlier tradition of net.art—which was created for and experienced through web browsers—Postinternet art arises from the experience of being online, even if it is not itself encountered in digital space. It is shaped by conditions such as “ubiquitous authorship, the development of attention as currency, the collapse of physical space in networked culture, and the infinite reproducibility and mutability of digital materials.” Yet this approach attracted significant critique. Opponents argued that Postinternet art’s political stance was vague, its criticality thin, and its methods complicit with the very capitalist logics it purported to expose—claiming the work didn’t address anything critically but instead merely capitalized on those structures. The resulting aesthetic is frequently characterized as “highly superficial, glossy, and seeped in indifference,” sometimes deploying “meme-like qualities to circulate through artistic and non-artistic networks.”.

bcaae6ec-3eac-4287-9a25-25ec3b2975eb.title: ICA Off-Site: Do You Follow? Art in Circulation #3
